## 

<span key="8b6d47fe82b046648318f215e707f3cd"><span offset-key="8b6d47fe82b046648318f215e707f3cd:0">What is GraphQL?</span></span>

<span key="7a8aa5e512f14ee7b4670656ec144a9d"><span offset-key="7a8aa5e512f14ee7b4670656ec144a9d:0">GraphQL is a specification for how to talk to an API. It's typically used over HTTP where the key idea is to </span>`POST`<span offset-key="7a8aa5e512f14ee7b4670656ec144a9d:2"> a "query" to an HTTP endpoint, instead of hitting different HTTP endpoints for different resources.</span></span>

<span key="887cfa04bed2467eb956e36b9537ee58"><span offset-key="887cfa04bed2467eb956e36b9537ee58:0">GraphQL is designed for developers of web/mobile apps (HTTP clients) to be able to make API calls to fetch the data they need from their backend APIs conveniently.</span></span>

## 

<span key="cfb2281943bc41979c09149f46b4cb85"><span offset-key="cfb2281943bc41979c09149f46b4cb85:0">GraphQL vs REST: an example</span></span>

<span key="440cdc51df28491c8f406db6fc9a064f"><span offset-key="440cdc51df28491c8f406db6fc9a064f:0">Let's say you have an API to fetch a user's profile and their address. In a typical REST scenario, this is what the request/response would look like:</span></span>

<img src="https://graphql-engine-cdn.hasura.io/learn-hasura/assets/graphql-react/rest-api.png" class="css-9pa8cd" draggable="false" />

<span key="2e5cd7cb53f9410482b9ba56a538791b"><span offset-key="2e5cd7cb53f9410482b9ba56a538791b:0">GraphQL API example</span></span>

<span key="b5207693e74c46c0a3022aa874e09966"><span offset-key="b5207693e74c46c0a3022aa874e09966:0">If your API server was a GraphQL server instead, this is what your API calls would look like:</span></span>

<img src="https://graphql-engine-cdn.hasura.io/learn-hasura/assets/graphql-react/graphql-api.gif" class="css-9pa8cd" draggable="false" />

<span key="ddbfa99ba8cf41c486585b21927b5921"><span offset-key="ddbfa99ba8cf41c486585b21927b5921:0">GraphQL API example</span></span>

<span key="a2cb9a4ed6b143d79e4402398922b587"><span offset-key="a2cb9a4ed6b143d79e4402398922b587:0">You can see that the response JSON is different for different "queries" sent by the client.</span></span>

1

<span key="53f3c5f2415b4f098987d1528d7fab8f"><span offset-key="53f3c5f2415b4f098987d1528d7fab8f:0">Request1: | Response1:query { | { user (id: 1) { | "user": { id | "id": 1 } | }} | }----------------------------------------Request2: | Response2:query { | { user (id: 1) { | "user": { id | "id": 1 name | "name": "Elmo" } | }} | }</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="0db2f130725542f1b290384f0dce8012"><span offset-key="0db2f130725542f1b290384f0dce8012:0">Thinking in GraphQL</span></span>

<span key="3a5986a659fe4ff0a91d3b69db733d35"><span offset-key="3a5986a659fe4ff0a91d3b69db733d35:0">We're changing the way we think about API calls. Instead of making different API calls to different URLs to fetch data, we're making ad-hoc queries to a "single URL endpoint" that returns data based on the query.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="b337734efa684202b5c77aa33e664b8b"><span offset-key="b337734efa684202b5c77aa33e664b8b:0">Instead of 'GET'ing a resource you 'POST' a query that describes what data you want.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="35c69f472aeb494f97a2f7096011af86"><span offset-key="35c69f472aeb494f97a2f7096011af86:0">You think of the data your API returns as a "graph", this allows you to make queries to fetch "related" pieces of data in a single shot. In the example above, you fetch the user and the user's address (as a nested JSON object) in the same API call, as opposed to making 2 API calls.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="a670e325650740d78db59a98c2e66d45"><span offset-key="a670e325650740d78db59a98c2e66d45:0">The "query" you send as data in the POST request has a structure and a syntax. This "language" is called GraphQL.</span></span>

<span key="eab1dc4d318842cdbacd47b05af5ada9"><span offset-key="eab1dc4d318842cdbacd47b05af5ada9:0">As you can see in the example above, GraphQL queries look very neat and easy to read! This is because the query is the "shape" of the final JSON data you desire. This is one of the key-reasons that makes GraphQL a joy to work with!</span></span>

## 

<span key="4177996541054537b905492ded529ec6"><span offset-key="4177996541054537b905492ded529ec6:0">GraphQL benefits</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="0b03ba61d8d44e7a8a89b7a1b4532250">**Avoid over-fetching**<span offset-key="0b03ba61d8d44e7a8a89b7a1b4532250:1">: You avoid fetching more data than you need because you can specify the exact </span>**fields**<span offset-key="0b03ba61d8d44e7a8a89b7a1b4532250:3"> you need.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="c602d1fae3434e548eef39d371befce9">**Prevent multiple API calls**<span offset-key="c602d1fae3434e548eef39d371befce9:1">: In case you need more data, you can also avoid making multiple calls to your API. In the case above, you don't need to make 2 API calls to fetch </span>`user`<span offset-key="c602d1fae3434e548eef39d371befce9:3"> and </span>`address`<span offset-key="c602d1fae3434e548eef39d371befce9:5"> separately.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="cc014ebeb0c74c1a86e4c3b0795a5ef3">**Lesser communication with API developers**<span offset-key="cc014ebeb0c74c1a86e4c3b0795a5ef3:1">: Sometimes to fetch the exact data you need, especially if you need to fetch more data and want to avoid multiple API calls, you will need to ask your API developers to build a new API. With GraphQL, your work is </span>*independent*<span offset-key="cc014ebeb0c74c1a86e4c3b0795a5ef3:3"> of the API team! This allows you to work faster on your app.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="ae35ce3bce3749c1b3d6341fa40de22d">**Self-documenting**<span offset-key="ae35ce3bce3749c1b3d6341fa40de22d:1">: Every GraphQL API conforms to a "schema" which is the graph data model and what kinds of queries a client can make. This allows the community to build lots of cool tools to explore & visualise your API or create IDE plugins that autocomplete your GraphQL queries and even do "codegen". We'll understand this in more detail later!</span></span>

<span key="141653741cdd40d4b1db859c91ee30d1"><span offset-key="141653741cdd40d4b1db859c91ee30d1:0">Here's a quick chart to show you the GraphQL analogs of typical REST-ish terms:</span></span>

Requirement

REST

GraphQL

<span key="bbd6dc8b62124a38acc937592a94ab02"><span offset-key="bbd6dc8b62124a38acc937592a94ab02:0">Fetching data objects</span></span>

<span key="f4459576d1c34d0a8398783df14fd972"><span offset-key="f4459576d1c34d0a8398783df14fd972:0">GET</span></span>

<span key="3bef70c96a92414c8022b2fc59a94865"><span offset-key="3bef70c96a92414c8022b2fc59a94865:0">query</span></span>

<span key="33d3db4b6d964a99a26a5ba331b70b7f"><span offset-key="33d3db4b6d964a99a26a5ba331b70b7f:0">Writing data</span></span>

<span key="766d324d38e944ac9ec8f3b35c926646"><span offset-key="766d324d38e944ac9ec8f3b35c926646:0">POST</span></span>

<span key="cecae752492a4e4f858419d0b79a64dd"><span offset-key="cecae752492a4e4f858419d0b79a64dd:0">mutation</span></span>

<span key="3e3879a6bdb64555845b7ba6a04d6d1d"><span offset-key="3e3879a6bdb64555845b7ba6a04d6d1d:0">Updating/deleting data</span></span>

<span key="90d7381fb3c3480fbdbeed3b892400ea"><span offset-key="90d7381fb3c3480fbdbeed3b892400ea:0">PUT/PATCH/DELETE</span></span>

<span key="8326b91ca4414f428dfa296ba9e61d10"><span offset-key="8326b91ca4414f428dfa296ba9e61d10:0">mutation</span></span>

<span key="94acc2b62997468fa14b3a5e0c4533db"><span offset-key="94acc2b62997468fa14b3a5e0c4533db:0">Watching/subscribing to data</span></span>

<span key="9e34217679bd43ee8c83588f70391714"><span offset-key="9e34217679bd43ee8c83588f70391714:0">-</span></span>

<span key="793dbcd41c1249acbd7cf1e4826e1a5e"><span offset-key="793dbcd41c1249acbd7cf1e4826e1a5e:0">subscription</span></span>

## 

<span key="1c6aa6775451459584a3d200bee5e247"><span offset-key="1c6aa6775451459584a3d200bee5e247:0">Try out GraphQL queries</span></span>

<span key="733586d27956468e9aa47c070af4dc0a"><span offset-key="733586d27956468e9aa47c070af4dc0a:0">For this tutorial we've set up a GraphQL API for you. The most common way to browse a GraphQL API is to use GraphiQL. GraphiQL is a tool built by Facebook, (pronounced "graphical") that makes it easy to explore any GraphQL API.</span></span>

<span key="75984ee2b0864e50b42337104fecfaea"><span offset-key="75984ee2b0864e50b42337104fecfaea:0">When you connect GraphiQL to a GraphQL endpoint, it queries the server for its GraphQL schema and gives you a UI to browse and test queries, and that powers its amazing autocomplete!</span></span>

<img src="https://graphql-engine-cdn.hasura.io/learn-hasura/assets/graphql-react/graphiql.gif" class="css-9pa8cd" draggable="false" />

<span key="18e57f2225ac498cab386a5b50c5901e"><span offset-key="18e57f2225ac498cab386a5b50c5901e:0">GraphiQL demo</span></span>

<span key="402f7a6eef394c04869d3bb7f5060ad0"><span offset-key="402f7a6eef394c04869d3bb7f5060ad0:0">Tools like GraphiQL make GraphQL APIs really easy to use and integrate APIs in your app without requiring external documentation tools.</span></span>

<span key="5cd2252894084be1953f33c9680f8544"><span offset-key="5cd2252894084be1953f33c9680f8544:0">You can access the GraphiQL for this realtime todo app tutorial here: </span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="965d6baa40cf4d949c68c7b5dfc5a6bb" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="c8d76bf9ebb44e65a65e95c048572d55"><span data-offset-key="c8d76bf9ebb44e65a65e95c048572d55:0">hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql</span></span></span></a><span key="8a46c0d2b1f94a84b9380fa1a766c876"><span offset-key="8a46c0d2b1f94a84b9380fa1a766c876:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="3cc3101d16a1405dbb5bed3d81acfd8b"><span offset-key="3cc3101d16a1405dbb5bed3d81acfd8b:0">When you work with a GraphQL API in a project you will almost always use a tool like GraphiQL to explore and test your GraphQL queries.</span></span>

## 

<span key="c3c93a7cbcf94283bde0bd77891394e2"><span offset-key="c3c93a7cbcf94283bde0bd77891394e2:0">Basic GraphQL query</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="44a093d598f44d28acc4c008bab08126"><span offset-key="44a093d598f44d28acc4c008bab08126:0">Open GraphiQL at: </span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="22d33be3e6c54d7095e8ff5faa6c34f3" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="1ea08edcfab543fb8abc8d328e4869fe"><span data-offset-key="1ea08edcfab543fb8abc8d328e4869fe:0">hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql</span></span></span></a><span key="03378c4fa84b40a59c3a0bc736a959e8"><span offset-key="03378c4fa84b40a59c3a0bc736a959e8:0">. You'll have to login to get an auth token to query the API. In a real-world scenario your GraphQL APIs will be protected.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="0eb0c66ee1da462fb75914c48ac7bf06"><span offset-key="0eb0c66ee1da462fb75914c48ac7bf06:0">You'll see a URL, and headers that contain the auth token that will be sent along with your GraphQL query.</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="5412ff67681d4662bac2f1ff0d9371e6"><span offset-key="5412ff67681d4662bac2f1ff0d9371e6:0">Now, paste this GraphQL query in the GraphiQL window</span></span>

1

<span key="9eb3c1f7569241bf8d6e6f6e6534c20d"><span offset-key="9eb3c1f7569241bf8d6e6f6e6534c20d:0"> query { users { name } }</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="b2a0fc4630324eabb7c4b69f1c05b2d6"><span offset-key="b2a0fc4630324eabb7c4b69f1c05b2d6:0">Hit </span>`ctrl + enter`<span offset-key="b2a0fc4630324eabb7c4b69f1c05b2d6:2"> or </span>`cmd + enter`<span offset-key="b2a0fc4630324eabb7c4b69f1c05b2d6:4"> (mac) or click on the ▶️ icon to run the GraphQL query</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="54fbcd05795a492c8ff5102e8e277bb5"><span offset-key="54fbcd05795a492c8ff5102e8e277bb5:0">On the right, you should see a list of users by their names that are in the system!</span></span>

<span key="bbdc9dd773104e75ba6395e210746bee"><span offset-key="bbdc9dd773104e75ba6395e210746bee:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b4e101c1ea5e48689236d0d680f68b7c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="e041dee58f8844e6bc3dabfb21729f59"><strong>Try it out in GraphiQL</strong></span></span></a><span key="2e2cf54c06b245288d9acee1216b0555"><span offset-key="2e2cf54c06b245288d9acee1216b0555:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="01c69539378f41c89f85dfe3a11e2dee"><span offset-key="01c69539378f41c89f85dfe3a11e2dee:0">Recall that there is no magic here! The hosted GraphiQL app is sending a GraphQL query string to the server at the given endpoint with the HTTP headers. The server then sends the response that you see on the right hand side.</span></span>

## 

<span key="7c0214ae66a3421196a298e240dc3f94"><span offset-key="7c0214ae66a3421196a298e240dc3f94:0">Fetching "graphs"</span></span>

<span key="2d4ca2ee63474fcb9ad907b99ccf7f60"><span offset-key="2d4ca2ee63474fcb9ad907b99ccf7f60:0">Our todo app has users, todos and information about users that are currently online. This is what our API "schema" looks like:</span></span>

<img src="https://graphql-engine-cdn.hasura.io/learn-hasura/assets/graphql-react/schema.png" class="css-9pa8cd" draggable="false" />

<span key="a49a9a5436c44be1a2fa4d07514f2aed"><span offset-key="a49a9a5436c44be1a2fa4d07514f2aed:0">Schema</span></span>

<span key="321322ac03414ccabe726568e8d585e3"><span offset-key="321322ac03414ccabe726568e8d585e3:0">As you can see, it is a "graph" like schema where all the 3 models are linked to each other.</span></span>

<span key="ccc124490e7648bfb8cde11d74412917"><span offset-key="ccc124490e7648bfb8cde11d74412917:0">Let's try making queries that fetch different slices of our data from the overall "graph".</span></span>

### 

<span key="cf2ac597eabb4597ae2e0f594092d4f5"><span offset-key="cf2ac597eabb4597ae2e0f594092d4f5:0">Fetch users and their todos</span></span>

<span key="189b77a76948462099afaf190c23ef1d"><span offset-key="189b77a76948462099afaf190c23ef1d:0">This GraphQL query will fetch all the users and their publicly visible todos:</span></span>

1

<span key="443a795296984040b82048d70ba2599f"><span offset-key="443a795296984040b82048d70ba2599f:0"> query { users { name todos { title } } }</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="be5675bf3fc74eb1baa6efe18c051b41"><span offset-key="be5675bf3fc74eb1baa6efe18c051b41:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="215908c7df7c4cbd8e1353c95711eb94" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="09e07647bc5440a4b5cc05cb13be01a1"><strong>Try it out in GraphiQL</strong></span></span></a><span key="dde417e5e832449e8d097956e47f6e34"><span offset-key="dde417e5e832449e8d097956e47f6e34:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

### 

<span key="00b10d4f9fa44cc59bdff49fe4fa4f2f"><span offset-key="00b10d4f9fa44cc59bdff49fe4fa4f2f:0">Fetch online users and their profile information</span></span>

<span key="2d0be37b2b4241eba8bb446c8960512e"><span offset-key="2d0be37b2b4241eba8bb446c8960512e:0">This GraphQL query will fetch all the currently online users and their profile information (which is just their name for now):</span></span>

1

<span key="f949427bad5741d3b8b89f7fdf022db5"><span offset-key="f949427bad5741d3b8b89f7fdf022db5:0"> query { online\_users { last\_seen user { name } } }</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="faf10014ee594e7b9b1a2d02f7c6cb9a"><span offset-key="faf10014ee594e7b9b1a2d02f7c6cb9a:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="1df74a92944d434cbcd928fab70c5a77" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="9193e993ea3344f2bf70a7767109bd0a"><strong>Try it out in GraphiQL</strong></span></span></a><span key="f1fe744802284d49b1cf6e363b6f6515"><span offset-key="f1fe744802284d49b1cf6e363b6f6515:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

## 

<span key="76ba75f8871447009c4e48a090eaf2fe"><span offset-key="76ba75f8871447009c4e48a090eaf2fe:0">Adding parameters (arguments) to GraphQL queries</span></span>

<span key="d46407ea65894358b89bf6e792792ddd"><span offset-key="d46407ea65894358b89bf6e792792ddd:0">In most API calls, you usually use parameters. For example, to specify what data you're fetching. If you're familiar with making </span>`GET`<span offset-key="d46407ea65894358b89bf6e792792ddd:2"> calls, you would have used a query parameter. For example, to fetch only 10 todos you might have made this API call: </span>`GET /api/todos?limit=10`<span offset-key="d46407ea65894358b89bf6e792792ddd:4">.</span></span>

<span key="a8d781560605414aa4b3c7343b394c55"><span offset-key="a8d781560605414aa4b3c7343b394c55:0">The GraphQL query analog of this is </span>*arguments*<span offset-key="a8d781560605414aa4b3c7343b394c55:2"> that you can attach to a "field".</span></span>

### 

<span key="26af78951a174c058178646ab4325acb"><span offset-key="26af78951a174c058178646ab4325acb:0">Basic argument: Fetch 10 todos</span></span>

<span key="583916639bcd4556a43d003a390786d8"><span offset-key="583916639bcd4556a43d003a390786d8:0">This GraphQL query will fetch 10 todos and not all of them.</span></span>

1

<span key="e17b1386828a4f809825a4351adc0b09"><span offset-key="e17b1386828a4f809825a4351adc0b09:0">query { todos(limit: 10) { id title }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="82be9dca4500456798cd12a6f323796f"><span offset-key="82be9dca4500456798cd12a6f323796f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="16c9a150499945e9a57ae6141dbe55e1" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="b0cc505634f3474290812bd04e9a8cd2"><strong>Try it out in GraphiQL</strong></span></span></a><span key="98db867255394571850364dc0bd8f2de"><span offset-key="98db867255394571850364dc0bd8f2de:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="5ba32b8f4fb84a5592519a5b185128c4"><span offset-key="5ba32b8f4fb84a5592519a5b185128c4:0">The most important bit to check here is </span>`limit: 10`<span offset-key="5ba32b8f4fb84a5592519a5b185128c4:2">. GraphQL servers will provide a list of arguments that can be used in </span>`()`<span offset-key="5ba32b8f4fb84a5592519a5b185128c4:4"> next to specific fields. In our case, we are using Hasura for creating the GraphQL backend which provides filter, sort and pagination arguments. The GraphQL server or API that you use, might provide a different set of arguments that can be used.</span></span>

### 

<span key="78017ada0fe84e56b24ec0292294b79c"><span offset-key="78017ada0fe84e56b24ec0292294b79c:0">Multiple arguments on multiple fields: Fetch 1 user and 5 most recent todos for each user</span></span>

1

<span key="483283d3f2dd4bf9ba674b3a67cb2ee4"><span offset-key="483283d3f2dd4bf9ba674b3a67cb2ee4:0">query { users (limit: 1) { id name todos(order\_by: {created\_at: desc}, limit: 5) { id title } }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="27dcb7402e944830b7e8ff8af058b6c8"><span offset-key="27dcb7402e944830b7e8ff8af058b6c8:0">Notice that we are passing arguments to different fields. This GraphQL query reads as:</span></span>

> <span key="d1904997df3f45f693e2b352a4041e45"><span offset-key="d1904997df3f45f693e2b352a4041e45:0">Fetch users (with limit 1), and their todos (ordered by descending creation time, and limited to 5).</span></span>

<span key="4ad5f5801f5540fba6e93a05e2a87252"><span offset-key="4ad5f5801f5540fba6e93a05e2a87252:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="ebcfde01e5a84d2eba45c58168dd855b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="d2349e77223a42899191374ec0f2e959"><strong>Try it out in GraphiQL</strong></span></span></a><span key="027fa5e2c4b9449384e6b80c42d34995"><span offset-key="027fa5e2c4b9449384e6b80c42d34995:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

## 

<span key="43f8f7ccd26b4c5abcc972543d2f046d"><span offset-key="43f8f7ccd26b4c5abcc972543d2f046d:0">GraphQL variables: Passing arguments to your queries dynamically</span></span>

<span key="c6eac9c1f2a045d990b955bae75d1864"><span offset-key="c6eac9c1f2a045d990b955bae75d1864:0">This is great, but we still have a problem. If we want to create a query where we are fetching data with arguments that are provided dynamically, we'd have to create the entire query string again.</span></span>

<span key="2743296a22c44c349775b7d3b16661f3"><span offset-key="2743296a22c44c349775b7d3b16661f3:0">This is what we don't want to do:</span></span>

1

<span key="0902ce9e8cb84e64b8790a9abb1445ca"><span offset-key="0902ce9e8cb84e64b8790a9abb1445ca:0">var limit = getMaxTodosFromUserInput();var query = "query { todos (limit: " + limit.toString() + ") {id title} }";</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c436f0e983174a6383fa0c3cb791e996"><span offset-key="c436f0e983174a6383fa0c3cb791e996:0">Thankfully, we don't ever have to do this! GraphQL variables are extra variables that you can send in a query so that the "arguments" can be provided dynamically!</span></span>

## 

<span key="d94ab99b82b640a1af270838a70ad0b1"><span offset-key="d94ab99b82b640a1af270838a70ad0b1:0">Fetch $limit number of todos</span></span>

<span key="ae8a86a6f1b742d9a89f4113c9c7cdf4"><span offset-key="ae8a86a6f1b742d9a89f4113c9c7cdf4:0">This is what our GraphQL query would look like:</span></span>

1

<span key="f5e2dff310284289a6645ee9652ca81c"><span offset-key="f5e2dff310284289a6645ee9652ca81c:0">query ($limit: Int!) { todos(limit: $limit) { id title }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0c9c67a51891495e8fc0d959fc774582"><span offset-key="0c9c67a51891495e8fc0d959fc774582:0">In addition to the query above, we send a variables object:</span></span>

1

<span key="406d52685e50473faa3eef43a5b412f5"><span offset-key="406d52685e50473faa3eef43a5b412f5:0">{ "limit": 10}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9a9a8274c37d4b688e77b1e1fa99536d"><span offset-key="9a9a8274c37d4b688e77b1e1fa99536d:0">Now instead of sending just the query to the GraphQL server, from our client we'll send both the query and the variables. The GraphQL server will use the variable in the right place in the query automatically for us!</span></span>

<span key="c4fc378e030349e587326601d03eee99"><span offset-key="c4fc378e030349e587326601d03eee99:0">Let's try this out in GraphiQL:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="0632b8da173148d582b1385fdbb1ee41"><span offset-key="0632b8da173148d582b1385fdbb1ee41:0">Head to GraphiQL</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="ce95434a544344a9963d732ab0f2172f"><span offset-key="ce95434a544344a9963d732ab0f2172f:0">Write out this query</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="c714961db9ae4e3f8f7b9d039bb1d2e7"><span offset-key="c714961db9ae4e3f8f7b9d039bb1d2e7:0">Scroll to the bottom of the page, where you see a smaller panel "Query Variables"</span></span>

4.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">4.</span>
    <span key="7a2d6d5208a84dd192aecd1e2c0c9ed8"><span offset-key="7a2d6d5208a84dd192aecd1e2c0c9ed8:0">Add the query variable as a JSON object</span></span>

<span key="5501c3f6f718485eadd5ebdde95a0e65"><span offset-key="5501c3f6f718485eadd5ebdde95a0e65:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="80927a8c53a64e10b242f64fdbccafc7" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="9f46a4e903f04de78b2f15591493ef65"><strong>Try it out in GraphiQL</strong></span></span></a><span key="67d4d94e910f49baa11f883b092597e3"><span offset-key="67d4d94e910f49baa11f883b092597e3:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="dd480927a73943f8b8831728a9bfaedc"><span offset-key="dd480927a73943f8b8831728a9bfaedc:0">Summary</span></span>

    <span key="c946e0ef4feb41bd9451d2a685e754f7"><span offset-key="c946e0ef4feb41bd9451d2a685e754f7:0">You can now make GraphQL queries</span></span>

    <span key="515c070245ac41828721c046df5846fc"><span offset-key="515c070245ac41828721c046df5846fc:0">You know how to pass arguments to your GraphQL queries</span></span>

    <span key="7b0eb0b2485c42faae733d7de9b5a2b9"><span offset-key="7b0eb0b2485c42faae733d7de9b5a2b9:0">You know how to make your arguments dynamic by using query variables</span></span>

# 

<span key="437dbeae4e9a4300b41c401d2b837ad3"><span offset-key="437dbeae4e9a4300b41c401d2b837ad3:0">Architecture</span></span>

<span key="d3be4e5469264333991d18bde7f26e0f"><span offset-key="d3be4e5469264333991d18bde7f26e0f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://github.com/hasura/learn-graphql/tree/master/tutorials/frontend/nextjs/tutorial-site/content/intro-to-graphql/1-architecture.md" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c74d932b7c064555bb7eec1bcb79f1c9" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="c31d4db73cf547839c92f3d09204e760"><span data-offset-key="c31d4db73cf547839c92f3d09204e760:0"><span data-slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span data-slate-void="true" data-key="cbb5709c5eb843af9b59a13c73ac06d5"><span></span></span></span></a>

<img src="https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/gitbook-x-prod.appspot.com/o/spaces%2F-MjLjuvITJh8ZwT8mVxp%2Fuploads%2FC5JzJzSjyw8S0TxePSrA%2Ffile.svg?alt=media" class="css-9pa8cd" draggable="false" />

<span key="98943fd44ff24f68b3b6edb1e402022b"><span offset-key="98943fd44ff24f68b3b6edb1e402022b:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span key="834efceec6dd44c9aafa59337d18cd55"><span offset-key="834efceec6dd44c9aafa59337d18cd55:0">Before going further in understanding GraphQL, it's useful to get a sense of how GraphQL is actually used in an HTTP client (typically a web/mobile app).</span></span>

## 

<span key="259323236dd5445f8f00c88a837fb25d"><span offset-key="259323236dd5445f8f00c88a837fb25d:0">GraphQL over HTTP</span></span>

<span key="8142b97d07ce4361877326d2b5366a99"><span offset-key="8142b97d07ce4361877326d2b5366a99:0">Check out the diagram below, to get a sense of how GraphQL is typically used in your stack:</span></span>

<img src="https://graphql-engine-cdn.hasura.io/learn-hasura/assets/graphql-react/graphql-on-http.png" class="css-9pa8cd" draggable="false" />

<span key="50b67d16d0674c4c94dabab1e4cbcb27"><span offset-key="50b67d16d0674c4c94dabab1e4cbcb27:0">GraphQL over HTTP</span></span>

### 

<span key="cdeecfaa242e4025922d7dadc033deda"><span offset-key="cdeecfaa242e4025922d7dadc033deda:0">GraphQL client-server flow:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="58fed7f37a244d40aba15e7b748b6e93"><span offset-key="58fed7f37a244d40aba15e7b748b6e93:0">Note that the GraphQL query is not really JSON; it looks like the shape of the JSON you </span>*want*<span offset-key="58fed7f37a244d40aba15e7b748b6e93:2">. So when we make a 'POST' request to send our GraphQL query to the server, it is sent as a "string" by the client.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="e5624761af6740c2ae1b1595902e713a"><span offset-key="e5624761af6740c2ae1b1595902e713a:0">The server gets the JSON object and extracts the query string. As per the GraphQL syntax and the graph data model (GraphQL schema), the server processes and validates the GraphQL query.</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="f6fcb347c243473dbd9bdbcbd01a5a43"><span offset-key="f6fcb347c243473dbd9bdbcbd01a5a43:0">Just like a typical API server, the GraphQL API server then makes calls to a database or other services to fetch the data that the client requested.</span></span>

4.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">4.</span>
    <span key="29f719cc64eb49e38d7b3084e4f52090"><span offset-key="29f719cc64eb49e38d7b3084e4f52090:0">The server then takes the data and returns it to the client in a JSON object.</span></span>

### 

<span key="a509a9fb97db41098d58d9f12ea0488c"><span offset-key="a509a9fb97db41098d58d9f12ea0488c:0">Example GraphQL client setup:</span></span>

<span key="abc729cf637641cc984dacafe2863efb"><span offset-key="abc729cf637641cc984dacafe2863efb:0">In your day to day work, you don't actually need to worry about the underlying HTTP requests & responses.</span></span>

<span key="7b7f837744554ce8913ca1891ff2f476"><span offset-key="7b7f837744554ce8913ca1891ff2f476:0">Just like when you work with a REST API and use a HTTP client to reduce the boilerplate in making API calls and handling responses, you can choose a GraphQL client to make writing GraphQL queries, sending them and handling responses much easier.</span></span>

<span key="d77ab52a1b8c47649a02280b0e5c40ce"><span offset-key="d77ab52a1b8c47649a02280b0e5c40ce:0">In fact, the mechanism of how you send the GraphQL query and accept the GraphQL response has become standard. This makes working with GraphQL very easy on the client.</span></span>

<span key="bb4869b7c310443f9dcc6acdabf6832a"><span offset-key="bb4869b7c310443f9dcc6acdabf6832a:0">Here's what a typical GraphQL client setup and making a query would look like:</span></span>

1

<span key="2b958eb245764ebe9ee578bc1205baa2"><span offset-key="2b958eb245764ebe9ee578bc1205baa2:0">// Setup a GraphQL client to use the endpointconst client = new client("https://myapi.com/graphql");// Now, send your query as a string (Note that \` is used to create a multi-line// string in javascript).client.query(\` query { user { id name } }\`);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="a0864502d15f4c8f9ea1d296b8b864c0"><span offset-key="a0864502d15f4c8f9ea1d296b8b864c0:0">Writing data - Mutations</span></span>

<span key="14006b7888d845c0925c75cf4956d0be"><span offset-key="14006b7888d845c0925c75cf4956d0be:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://github.com/hasura/learn-graphql/tree/master/tutorials/frontend/nextjs/tutorial-site/content/intro-to-graphql/3-writing-data-mutations.md" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="480353894d374b48bdb93dc497f63e94" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="ac528c33e4ea4e15a3ae64c8c327270e"><span data-offset-key="ac528c33e4ea4e15a3ae64c8c327270e:0"><span data-slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span data-slate-void="true" data-key="e454834134184545b1f0f9c4f4028b28"><span></span></span></span></a>

<img src="https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/gitbook-x-prod.appspot.com/o/spaces%2F-MjLjuvITJh8ZwT8mVxp%2Fuploads%2FrLlP1sdYa4yd1CdLcJgW%2Ffile.svg?alt=media" class="css-9pa8cd" draggable="false" />

<span key="311b99ad30d541138efd4e4b09eb9e71"><span offset-key="311b99ad30d541138efd4e4b09eb9e71:0">Edit on GitHub</span></span><span key="64a8127e88ea48c8aeefab3682a6d39f"><span offset-key="64a8127e88ea48c8aeefab3682a6d39f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="708d6cbc98eb4947af66af5ef4480d8f"><span offset-key="708d6cbc98eb4947af66af5ef4480d8f:0">These are the concepts you should know before you attack mutations (haha):</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="b7ddceeeb824473abcf6d913319a51de"><span offset-key="b7ddceeeb824473abcf6d913319a51de:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/nextjs-fullstack-serverless/intro-to-graphql/2-fetching-data-queries/#tryoutgraphqlqueries" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b52305a7d20b43ac98213fcb44ebc896" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="251716b24ff34f88ad53a9936d9079c1"><span data-offset-key="251716b24ff34f88ad53a9936d9079c1:0">Using GraphiQL</span></span></span></a><span key="d917035607f9484bb941950d14a22985"><span offset-key="d917035607f9484bb941950d14a22985:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="94e4d1a55a6c4f26829da83d4523c50b"><span offset-key="94e4d1a55a6c4f26829da83d4523c50b:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/nextjs-fullstack-serverless/intro-to-graphql/2-fetching-data-queries/#graphqlvariables:passingargumentstoyourqueriesdynamically" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="ba02218c541a4eccb7da6ab270a7ff28" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="e7cb31cdc552490c936d8c008bd7faaa"><span data-offset-key="e7cb31cdc552490c936d8c008bd7faaa:0">Using query variables</span></span></span></a><span key="49dcb388e2924338bcdfb1efbca671fe"><span offset-key="49dcb388e2924338bcdfb1efbca671fe:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="eeec8e3ffdd240d7966f25632416b8c7"><span offset-key="eeec8e3ffdd240d7966f25632416b8c7:0">Now, let's get started with seeing how we can use GraphQL to "write" data. GraphQL mutations are types of GraphQL queries that may result in the state of your backend "mutating" or changing, just like typical </span>`'POST'`<span offset-key="eeec8e3ffdd240d7966f25632416b8c7:2">, </span>`'PUT'`<span offset-key="eeec8e3ffdd240d7966f25632416b8c7:4">, </span>`'PATCH'`<span offset-key="eeec8e3ffdd240d7966f25632416b8c7:6">, </span>`'DELETE'`<span offset-key="eeec8e3ffdd240d7966f25632416b8c7:8"> APIs.</span></span>

## 

<span key="6c6d368335ff4cfeba3b675fc253234f"><span offset-key="6c6d368335ff4cfeba3b675fc253234f:0">Basic mutations</span></span>

<span key="702f1c11538a435fa77732e26f57ce1a"><span offset-key="702f1c11538a435fa77732e26f57ce1a:0">Since we're using Hasura for our GraphQL API, we get mutations for inserts, updates or deletes that we can use in our app.</span></span>

<span key="a3de76212eea4a97ab6a179e2782ecdf"><span offset-key="a3de76212eea4a97ab6a179e2782ecdf:0">Let's try these mutations out in the context of a todo app to see what mutations look like. Mutations that you get from another GraphQL service, say if your API team has built their own, might be different.</span></span>

### 

<span key="5b865f37397d4aa68a9b52193652e633"><span offset-key="5b865f37397d4aa68a9b52193652e633:0">Create a todo</span></span>

<span key="ca0ab23073034ce88d77bc3a7e6b7891"><span offset-key="ca0ab23073034ce88d77bc3a7e6b7891:0">Let's make an API call to create a todo. As you would have guessed, this will be a critical portion of our todo app. 😉</span></span>

> <span key="684ab2fa13ed447297d2458413cd4158">**Protip**<span offset-key="684ab2fa13ed447297d2458413cd4158:1">: Now let's say we don't know what the name of the mutation to create a todo. GraphiQL to the rescue! Head to GraphiQL and on the right, click on the "docs" tab. Type "todo" there and you'll see a list of GraphQL queries and types that use todo. Read through their descriptions and you'll soon find that </span>`insert_todos`<span offset-key="684ab2fa13ed447297d2458413cd4158:3"> is what you need.</span></span>

<span key="92e348016fdb4c6ab00ab855d5735ec0"><span offset-key="92e348016fdb4c6ab00ab855d5735ec0:0">The mutation to create todos is titled </span>`insert_todos`<span offset-key="92e348016fdb4c6ab00ab855d5735ec0:2">.</span></span>

1

<span key="f4bbf919b7994f5488d26728ac82d96f"><span offset-key="f4bbf919b7994f5488d26728ac82d96f:0">mutation { insert\_todos(objects: \[{title: "new todo"}\]) { returning { id } }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="70283507080048bd95b7c217ee16ff81"><span offset-key="70283507080048bd95b7c217ee16ff81:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="91370299b03f40d3a32ae2433d7a65b3" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="fce9e19ef39c49fcaa58158806adbf83"><strong>Try it out in GraphiQL</strong></span></span></a><span key="d9fd7ed6188844e18e332cc047cfa189"><span offset-key="d9fd7ed6188844e18e332cc047cfa189:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

## 

<span key="582e8ca8f875468eb1afc144595f9083"><span offset-key="582e8ca8f875468eb1afc144595f9083:0">Returning data after the mutation</span></span>

<span key="c3cdf81ec4da469491ffc9ef274462fd"><span offset-key="c3cdf81ec4da469491ffc9ef274462fd:0">Notice that the data of the todo that is to be inserted is sent as an argument to the </span>`insert_todos`<span offset-key="c3cdf81ec4da469491ffc9ef274462fd:2"> mutation. But the "fields" of the mutation specify the shape of the </span>*response*<span offset-key="c3cdf81ec4da469491ffc9ef274462fd:4"> that you want from the server.</span></span>

<span key="dad8a73110144d31a9700e4a8a2f5a75"><span offset-key="dad8a73110144d31a9700e4a8a2f5a75:0">Let's say we'd like to get the entire todo object once it's been created as a response:</span></span>

1

<span key="304055cb19fe4a62b81893cc1c3d0b18"><span offset-key="304055cb19fe4a62b81893cc1c3d0b18:0">mutation { insert\_todos(objects: \[{title: "new todo"}\]) { returning { id title is\_completed is\_public created\_at } }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c88a769387914260b9432bb5ee172ded"><span offset-key="c88a769387914260b9432bb5ee172ded:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3b8ac8bb89f34a1db01fcb95d90ca95e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="f4124900683d4e7d9338eac9c465b30e"><strong>Try it out in GraphiQL</strong></span></span></a><span key="5ed1c316f39242dcbc01dfec8359356f"><span offset-key="5ed1c316f39242dcbc01dfec8359356f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

## 

<span key="bde1268244a5443686f915aa1c358ddc"><span offset-key="bde1268244a5443686f915aa1c358ddc:0">Parameterise what you insert</span></span>

<span key="883def2bcbd940308bcba89238cd5f3e"><span offset-key="883def2bcbd940308bcba89238cd5f3e:0">For mutations, we would almost always have to parameterise the arguments! We would rarely, if ever, have a "hardcoded" mutation in our app. This is because the arguments of what data to capture, how to modify or delete something is usually dependent on some user action.</span></span>

<span key="0a7791b4c7aa4910a6256855fbc25323"><span offset-key="0a7791b4c7aa4910a6256855fbc25323:0">Now that we know how to parameterise using query variables, let's use that:</span></span>

1

<span key="9152794acadf47389e8bb87e86112dce"><span offset-key="9152794acadf47389e8bb87e86112dce:0"># The parameterised GraphQL mutationmutation($todo: todos\_insert\_input!){ insert\_todos(objects: \[$todo\]) { returning { id } }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

1

<span key="6022ec6eef634ec39b5aa1ac6fe531c0"><span offset-key="6022ec6eef634ec39b5aa1ac6fe531c0:0"># As a query variable{ "todo": { "title": "A new dynamic todo" }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f7ae883dbb1648ba9932c582e52f31af"><span offset-key="f7ae883dbb1648ba9932c582e52f31af:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="ab776622d6e042c499c7889c406bf430" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="156e7ff43da145bb94a3a0dafaa90a7d"><strong>Try it out in GraphiQL</strong></span></span></a><span key="714532511e3a4a3bb83308332f800cd1"><span offset-key="714532511e3a4a3bb83308332f800cd1:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="664c313538914acca701597f1a5253cc"><span offset-key="664c313538914acca701597f1a5253cc:0">We'll explore more mutations to update or delete data a little later. This is a good start to grokking mutations!</span></span>

## 

<span key="6f3db05013ef4d81856b0f73069a05e2"><span offset-key="6f3db05013ef4d81856b0f73069a05e2:0">Summary</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="dbaab9d738664082a7810b261927d68b"><span offset-key="dbaab9d738664082a7810b261927d68b:0">You can make basic GraphQL mutations</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="70f696172b7a4c5ab6fd5f2f54ec8453"><span offset-key="70f696172b7a4c5ab6fd5f2f54ec8453:0">You can pass dynamic arguments/data to mutations with query variables</span></span>

<span key="76c1886bc3c44db19ea898035fa7aa05"><span offset-key="76c1886bc3c44db19ea898035fa7aa05:0">Next, let's look at GraphQL subscriptions</span></span>

# 

<span key="48cfd00ba9bf4040a7feed85e0c0f60e"><span offset-key="48cfd00ba9bf4040a7feed85e0c0f60e:0">Watching data - Subscriptions</span></span>

<span key="6bf3284d3b7a4185a98564e9c0573852"><span offset-key="6bf3284d3b7a4185a98564e9c0573852:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://github.com/hasura/learn-graphql/tree/master/tutorials/frontend/nextjs/tutorial-site/content/intro-to-graphql/4-watching-data-subscriptions.md" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="90d414342a6444bf8221ae6aaf61e686" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="556d199b6e1f47b098bb38aec19fb903"><span data-offset-key="556d199b6e1f47b098bb38aec19fb903:0"><span data-slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span data-slate-void="true" data-key="132444fdc4624948b730acab6f1ca016"><span></span></span></span></a>

<img src="https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/gitbook-x-prod.appspot.com/o/spaces%2F-MjLjuvITJh8ZwT8mVxp%2Fuploads%2FKAMsK050B7txng9nxtOj%2Ffile.svg?alt=media" class="css-9pa8cd" draggable="false" />

<span key="e3c7812b90fe417abd5874c54c8646b4"><span offset-key="e3c7812b90fe417abd5874c54c8646b4:0">Edit on GitHub</span></span><span key="ab98d3ef006a46aa9b5becfbbc54bbdf"><span offset-key="ab98d3ef006a46aa9b5becfbbc54bbdf:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="b993f4b1c3b94495814b215a0091bbdc"><span offset-key="b993f4b1c3b94495814b215a0091bbdc:0">The GraphQL specification allows for something called subscriptions that are like GraphQL queries but instead of returning data in one read, you get data pushed from the server.</span></span>

<span key="1c6df36e5b25447aa4240952edfcab2c"><span offset-key="1c6df36e5b25447aa4240952edfcab2c:0">This is useful for your app to subscribe to "events" or "live results" from the backend, but while allowing you to control the "shape" of the event from your app.</span></span>

<span key="1351b168b78641ec9161a78784e36157"><span offset-key="1351b168b78641ec9161a78784e36157:0">GraphQL subscriptions are a critical component of adding realtime or reactive features to your apps easily. GraphQL clients and servers that support subscriptions are great because they allow you to build great experiences without having to deal with websocket code!</span></span>

## 

<span key="17911017520d43ab9fc5bc893ce9206c"><span offset-key="17911017520d43ab9fc5bc893ce9206c:0">Make your first GraphQL subscription</span></span>

<span key="8280fec9f7904854b060923d8216272f"><span offset-key="8280fec9f7904854b060923d8216272f:0">Step 1: Head to </span></span><a href="https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="373026a9f9354988af1e6564a6399f03" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_260-4577_262-4578-240__"><span data-key="56c2b245f2704787947b961a991cfa0f"><span data-offset-key="56c2b245f2704787947b961a991cfa0f:0">https://hasura.io/learn/graphql/graphiql</span></span></span></a><span key="69c6b59ee28645148815b7197ca893dc"><span offset-key="69c6b59ee28645148815b7197ca893dc:0"> Step 2: Write this GraphQL query in the textarea:</span></span>

1

<span key="1c969b531e6a42c78dc4460b73aacff0"><span offset-key="1c969b531e6a42c78dc4460b73aacff0:0">subscription { online\_users { id last\_seen user { name } }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1cb19ee6b7514902a79e3d75238d3f5a"><span offset-key="1cb19ee6b7514902a79e3d75238d3f5a:0">Step 3: Click on the play button.</span></span>

<span key="9c3dd4011ed64a34b6e407a7cef99552"><span offset-key="9c3dd4011ed64a34b6e407a7cef99552:0">Every time the set of online users change, you'll see the latest set on the response window on the right.</span></span>

## 

<span key="b0dc131251414fb3aafa115e04e3687c"><span offset-key="b0dc131251414fb3aafa115e04e3687c:0">How do GraphQL subscriptions work?</span></span>

<span key="5eecaa9bc4dd42b39b85b32ce1f718aa"><span offset-key="5eecaa9bc4dd42b39b85b32ce1f718aa:0">GraphQL queries and mutations are strings sent to a POST endpoint. What is a GraphQL subscription? That can't happen over a POST endpoint, because a simple HTTP endpoint would just return the response and the connection would close.</span></span>

<span key="213f4bc953d849bdb1b24607edbaaf21"><span offset-key="213f4bc953d849bdb1b24607edbaaf21:0">A GraphQL subscription is a subscription query string sent to a websocket endpoint. And whenever data changes on the backend, new data is pushed over websockets from the server to the client.</span></span>

## 

<span key="ebcd7eeb00c7463b8f66a02b7b08843b"><span offset-key="ebcd7eeb00c7463b8f66a02b7b08843b:0">Summary</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="83b2586d931c4e5e9817ca942abfbef2"><span offset-key="83b2586d931c4e5e9817ca942abfbef2:0">You know how to make GraphQL subscriptions</span></span>

<span key="0ebdbf634b9b40c986e0bd22cf84136d"><span offset-key="0ebdbf634b9b40c986e0bd22cf84136d:0">Now that you're comfortable with the basics of using GraphQL, let's start integrating GraphQL APIs with an app!</span></span><span slate-void="true" key="1a8194a3a4c548c78c172071c9685878"></span>
